title: Memorials and remains of medical research in Africa: an anthropology of scientific landscapes, ruins and artefacts
abstractText: Abstracts are not currently available in GtR for all funded research. This is normally because the abstract was not required at the time of proposal submission, but may be because it included sensitive information such as personal details.
impactText: Our findings have been used by artists working on aspects of memory, health, and ecology, and by heritage entrepreneurs and scholars in African host states and communities. Creative Economy,Education,Healthcare,Culture, Heritage, Museums and Collections Cultural,Societal
findingsText:
We have shed light on how international public health practices have evolved in response to colonial, developmental and neoliberal visions of Africa and the ways in which landscapes, bodies, personal memories and institutions in Africa have been differently inscribed by the trajectories of medical science.

This collaborative enterprise has thus enriched comparative imperial and post-colonial history, sociological understandings of science, the anthropology of African modernities, and international medical research ethics. Scientific partner organisations in the global North and in Africa stand to benefit by increased attention to the remains and aftereffects of infrastructural work in health and medical research. Heritage organisations will derive benefit from the documentation and conceptual work performed by the research team in recuperating significant sites and their social and material aspects, and reinserting them into conversations around commemoration and patrimony, and into circulation among cultural workers in museums and the arts.
